trans-unit.source: Difference in Proportions Test | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Difference in Proportions Test | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Difference in Proportions Test
trans-unit.target: Difference in Proportions Test

trans-unit.source: Difference in Proportions Test
trans-unit.target: Difference in Proportions Test

trans-unit.source: Are two proportions statistically different?
trans-unit.target: Are two proportions statistically different?

trans-unit.source: Suppose a user wants to compare two movies to determine if one movie has a significantly higher proportion of ‘likes’ when compared to the other.
trans-unit.target: Suppose a user wants to compare two movies to determine if one movie has a significantly higher proportion of ‘likes’ when compared to the other.

trans-unit.source: With a large sample, there could be a statistically significant difference between the proportions 0.50 and 0.51.
trans-unit.target: With a large sample, there could be a statistically significant difference between the proportions 0.50 and 0.51.

trans-unit.source: With a small sample, there may not be enough data to determine if these proportions are actually different.
trans-unit.target: With a small sample, there may not be enough data to determine if these proportions are actually different.

trans-unit.source: This [web service]( https://datamarket.azure.com/dataset/aml_labs/prop_test) conducts a hypothesis test of the difference in two proportions based on user input of the number of successes and the total number of trials for the 2 comparison groups.
trans-unit.target: This [web service]( https://datamarket.azure.com/dataset/aml_labs/prop_test) conducts a hypothesis test of the difference in two proportions based on user input of the number of successes and the total number of trials for the 2 comparison groups.

trans-unit.source: In one possible scenario, this web service could be called from within a movie comparison app, telling the user whether one of the movies is really ‘liked’ more often than the other, based on movie ratings.
trans-unit.target: In one possible scenario, this web service could be called from within a movie comparison app, telling the user whether one of the movies is really ‘liked’ more often than the other, based on movie ratings.

trans-unit.source: This web service could be consumed by users – potentially through a mobile app, through a website, or even on a local computer, for example.
trans-unit.target: This web service could be consumed by users – potentially through a mobile app, through a website, or even on a local computer, for example.

trans-unit.source: But the purpose of the web service is also to serve as an example of how Azure Machine Learning can be used to create web services on top of R code.
trans-unit.target: But the purpose of the web service is also to serve as an example of how Azure Machine Learning can be used to create web services on top of R code.

trans-unit.source: With just a few lines of R code and clicks of a button within Azure Machine Learning Studio, an experiment can be created with R code and published as a web service.
trans-unit.target: With just a few lines of R code and clicks of a button within Azure Machine Learning Studio, an experiment can be created with R code and published as a web service.

trans-unit.source: The web service can then be published to the Azure Marketplace and consumed by users and devices across the world with no infrastructure setup by the author of the web service.
trans-unit.target: The web service can then be published to the Azure Marketplace and consumed by users and devices across the world with no infrastructure setup by the author of the web service.

trans-unit.source: Consumption of web service
trans-unit.target: Consumption of web service

trans-unit.source: This service accepts 4 arguments and does a hypothesis test of proportions.
trans-unit.target: This service accepts 4 arguments and does a hypothesis test of proportions.

trans-unit.source: The input arguments are:
trans-unit.target: The input arguments are:

trans-unit.source: Successes1 - Number of success events in sample 1.
trans-unit.target: Successes1 - Number of success events in sample 1.

trans-unit.source: Successes2 - Number of success events in sample 2.
trans-unit.target: Successes2 - Number of success events in sample 2.

trans-unit.source: Total1 - Size of sample 1.
trans-unit.target: Total1 - Size of sample 1.

trans-unit.source: Total2 - Size of sample 2.
trans-unit.target: Total2 - Size of sample 2.

trans-unit.source: The output of the service is the result of the hypothesis test along with the chi-square statistic, df, p-value, and proportion in sample 1/2 and confidence interval bounds.
trans-unit.target: The output of the service is the result of the hypothesis test along with the chi-square statistic, df, p-value, and proportion in sample 1/2 and confidence interval bounds.

trans-unit.source: This service, as hosted on the Azure Marketplace, is an OData service; these may be called through POST or GET methods.
trans-unit.target: This service, as hosted on the Azure Marketplace, is an OData service; these may be called through POST or GET methods.

trans-unit.source: There are multiple ways of consuming the service in an automated fashion (an example app is [here](http://microsoftazuremachinelearning.azurewebsites.net/DifferenceInProportionsTest.aspx )).
trans-unit.target: There are multiple ways of consuming the service in an automated fashion (an example app is [here](http://microsoftazuremachinelearning.azurewebsites.net/DifferenceInProportionsTest.aspx )).

trans-unit.target: Starting C# code for web service consumption:

trans-unit.source: Creation of web service
trans-unit.target: Creation of web service

trans-unit.source: This web service was created using Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: This web service was created using Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: For a free trial, as well as introductory videos on creating experiments and [publishing web services](machine-learning-publish-a-machine-learning-web-service.md), please see [azure.com/ml](http://azure.com/ml).
trans-unit.target: For a free trial, as well as introductory videos on creating experiments and [publishing web services](machine-learning-publish-a-machine-learning-web-service.md), please see [azure.com/ml](http://azure.com/ml).

trans-unit.source: Below is a screenshot of the experiment that created the web service and example code for each of the modules within the experiment.
trans-unit.target: Below is a screenshot of the experiment that created the web service and example code for each of the modules within the experiment.

trans-unit.source: From within Azure Machine Learning, a new blank experiment was created with two [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] modules.
trans-unit.target: From within Azure Machine Learning, a new blank experiment was created with two [Execute R Script][execute-r-script] modules.

trans-unit.source: In the first module the data schema is defined, while the second module uses the prop.test command within R to perform the hypothesis test for 2 proportions.
trans-unit.target: In the first module the data schema is defined, while the second module uses the prop.test command within R to perform the hypothesis test for 2 proportions.

trans-unit.source: Experiment flow:
trans-unit.target: Experiment flow:

trans-unit.source: Experiment flow
trans-unit.target: Experiment flow

trans-unit.source: Module 1:
trans-unit.target: Module 1:

trans-unit.source: Schema definition
trans-unit.target: Schema definition

trans-unit.source: data.set=data.frame(successes1=50,successes2=60,total1=100,total2=100);
trans-unit.target: data.set=data.frame(successes1=50,successes2=60,total1=100,total2=100);

trans-unit.source: maml.mapOutputPort("data.set"); #send data to output port
trans-unit.target: maml.mapOutputPort("data.set"); #send data to output port

trans-unit.source: dataset1 = maml.mapInputPort(1) #read data from input port
trans-unit.target: dataset1 = maml.mapInputPort(1) #read data from input port

trans-unit.source: Module 2:
trans-unit.target: Module 2:

trans-unit.source: Limitations
trans-unit.target: Limitations

trans-unit.source: This is a very simple example for a test of difference in 2 proportions.
trans-unit.target: This is a very simple example for a test of difference in 2 proportions.

trans-unit.source: As can be seen from the example code above, no error catching is implemented and the service assumes that all the variables are continuous.
trans-unit.target: As can be seen from the example code above, no error catching is implemented and the service assumes that all the variables are continuous.
